explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures; the auto-ignition temperature is 402degC (ICSC, 2002)

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 6,300 mg/kg representing the lowest testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 6,300mg/kg and 8,000mg/kg, (EU-RAR No.29 (2003)), and over 20,000mg/kg (EHC 189, 1997). However acute toxicity was observed from a human case where a 23-year old male worker accidentally swallowed about 10g of the substance and suffered acute toxicity (EU-RAR No.29, 2003).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rabbit LD50 (dermal route) of over 20,000 mg/kg (EU-RAR No.29 (2003)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (mist) of over 15.68 mg/L (EU-RAR No.29 (2003)).

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.11 (2004) and EU-RAR No.29 (2003): The substance is "slightly to moderately irritating."

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.11 (2004) and EU-RAR No.29 (2003): The substance has irritation to eyes but recovery observed 48 or 72 hours later.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory Sensitizer: Classification not possible Skin Sensitizer: Category 1
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Respiratory sensitizer: No data available Skin sensitizer: phthalic acid di-n-butyl does not cause skin sensitization in experimental animals (EU-RAR No.29 (2003), EHC 189 (1997)); some human cases suggest positive results; classified into "Skin Sensitization Group 2" by the Japan Society for Occupational Health (2005), and into "Skin Sensitization: Positive" by the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of positive data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests and germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, and negative data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, described in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.11 (2004).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category D by EPA (1993).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Based on the description in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.11 (2004): Rat and mouse reproductive toxicity tests suggest a decrease in F0 reproductive potential, testis atrophy, a decrease in sperm production potential, abortion during the middle stages of pregnancy, a decrease in litter size; Rat and mouse teratogenicity tests suggest malformations in offspring (external/skeletal malformations), and developmental abnormalities in the testes and accessory reproductive gland of next-generation rats; General toxicity to parental animals is observed; No description is available for the effects on parental animals.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 1 (kidneys, nervous system) Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "large amounts of red/white blood cells in urinary sediments" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.11 (2004)), and the evidence from animal studies including "constrained respiration, ataxia, local paralysis, convulsions, coma, fatal cases in some animals due to respiratory paralysis" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.11 (2004)), "obvious irritation to the upper respiratory tract mucous membrane" (EU-RAR No.29 (2004)). The effects on nervous system of experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "seminiferous tubule degeneration, interstitial edema" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.11 (2004)), "hepatic atrophy and zonal necrosis" (EHC 189 (1997)), "dose-dependent acanthosis of the nasal mucous membrane" (EU-RAR No.29 (2004)). The effects on the respiratory organs and on the testes and liver of experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1 and Category 2, respectively.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 96 hours LC50=0.46mg/L of the fish (American Catfish) (EU-RAR (2004) and others.).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since there was rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 69% (Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)) and the bio-accumulation was low (BCF=176 (Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was claasified into Not classified.
